points.title: Despite awareness of recommendations, why do not health care workers not immunize pregnant women?
points.digest: In spite of the fact that 93% of doctors know that the Ministry of Health recommends vaccinating pregnant women against influenza and pertussis, only 70% follow these recommendations.

points.title: How do physicians immunize their own children? Differences among pediatricians and nonpediatricians.
points.digest:
5% of non-pediatric doctors do not vaccinate their children from measles-mumps-rubella, they believe that combined vaccines are not safe, that it is better to have the disease than to be vaccinated, and that homeopathic treatment works well for these diseases. % will postpone the DTAP vaccination at a later date, 15% will postpone the MMR vaccination.

A third of doctors did not vaccinate their children against hepatitis B and hemophilic rods, only 12% were vaccinated against influenza, and only 3% were vaccinated against chickenpox. did not vaccinate their children according to the schedule of vaccinations.
The survey involved l all InfoVac subscribers, that is, doctors who are actively interested in vaccination, which means that the real number of doctors who do not vaccinate their children is probably much larger. (Switzerland)

points.title: Vaccination practices among physicians and their children.
points.digest: 21% of specialist pediatricians and 10% of general pediatricians will refuse at least one vaccination for their child.

Only 10% of doctors had a good opinion about all vaccines.

points.title: Factors associated with vaccination for hepatitis B, pertussis, seasonal and pandemic influenza among French general practitioners: a 2010 survey.
points.digest: 27% of family doctors were not vaccinated against hepatitis B, 36% were not vaccinated against pertussis, 23% were not vaccinated against influenza.

points.title: Knowledge, attitudes, beliefs and practices of general practitioners towards measles and MMR vaccination in southeastern France in 2012.
points.digest: 13% of doctors do not consider measles a dangerous disease.

points.title: What lies behind the low rates of vaccinations among nurses who treat infants?
points.digest:
After the Israeli nurses were asked to get a cough for whooping cough for 3 months, only 2% (two percent) deigned to do it, and this refers to nurses working in mother and child centers (type hlavav), that is, those whose main role is to vaccinate children.
Most nurses do not trust health authorities, and desperately resist mandatory vaccinations.
Nurses fear side effects and believe that the risk from influenza and pertussis is lower than the risk from They believe that parents should have a choice, Do not or do not vaccinate a child, and require the same respect for their rights.

Nurses share work and personal life.The fact that their job is to vaccinate children is one thing: whether they are vaccinated themselves or not, it is their personal case, and they do not consider it necessary to inform parents about their opinion about vaccinations, or about whether they are vaccinated themselves. The authors of the study concluded that nurses who make vaccinations are essentially anti-vaccination drugs. (Israel)

This is probably the most important study, of all presented here. Practically in all other studies, the data were collected from a survey of doctors. Doctors perfectly understand that they should not negatively react about vaccinations, so it is logical to assume that the real number of doctors who do not vaccinate their children is much higher. The data in this study is real, they are not based on surveys. 98% of nurses, whose main role is to make children vaccinated, refuse to vaccinate themselves!
Israeli doctors, however, too [refuse == https: //www.vesty.co.il/articles /0,7340,L-5028846,00.html] vaccinated against influenza.

points.title: Influenza vaccination among healthcare workers in Italy.
points.digest: Health workers are resistant to influenza vaccinations, despite 10 years of efforts to increase the level of vaccination, only 30% of doctors, 11% of nurses and 9% of clinical staff are vaccinated against influenza.

points.title: Vaccinating health care workers during an influenza pandemic.
points.digest: 41% of health workers refused to get vaccinated against swine flu during the 2009 pandemic.
57% of the workers in the system public health services refused to be vaccinated against routine influenza. (London, UK)

points.title: Influenza vaccination amongst hospital health care workers in Beijing.
points.digest: Only 13% of physicians and 21% of nurses are vaccinated against influenza.
(Beijing, China)

points.title: Influenza vaccination compliance among health care workers in a German university hospital.
points.digest: Over 20 years of German health workers are being persuaded to get vaccinated against the flu, but only 39% of doctors and 17% of nurses are vaccinated.

points.title: Influenza vaccination attitudes and practices among US registered nurses.
points.digest: 41% of nurses did not get vaccinated against the flu, they feared side effects, believed that the risk of contracting a low, and in general, did not consider this vaccine effective. (USA)
